newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine '97 budget sees 5 pct growth - Fernandez.
newsitem.headline: Argentine '97 budget sees 5 pct growth - Fernandez.

text.p: Argentina's Economy Minister Roque Fernandez presented Congress Friday with a blueprint for the 1997 budget including a forecast for five percent economic growth.

The draft presented to the lower house's Budget Committee also sees real investment rising 10 percent and a total budget deficit of $3.0 billion, equivalent to 1.0 percent of the country's gross domestic product.
The draft said the government expected to close the fiscal gap in the short term and have a balanced budget in 1998.
The project includes an expected 4.3 percent rise in consumption. Exports are expected to rise by 7.0 percent and imports by 9.6 percent.

Total public expenditure is seen at $43.0 billion and total revenue at $41.0 billion. That would represent a $1.96 billion gap, but after the expected deficit of the province's pension funds transferred to the central government is added, the total budget deficit would be $3.0 billion.
The foreign trade forecast includes an expected $27.53 billion in exports and $29.43 billion in imports -- a $1.9 billion deficit. This compares with an expected surplus of $800 million this year.
Combined consumer and wholesale inflation is estimated at 2.0 percent.
The 1997 forecast also contemplates maintaining the peso-dollar parity introduced by Fernandez's predecessor Domingo Cavallo in 1991.
The draft will now be discussed at committee level before going to the floor. It must be approved before year's end.
